template.name: Robot

transition.label: ND[id] == R
done[id] = true, allDone = count(done) == R ? 1 : 0, sameCycle = allSameTimestamp(cycle)
Verification updates
compareCycle() && ND[id] != R
updateP(), decision[id] = maxIndex(P[id]), prefsUpdated[id] = true, DUpdated[id] = false
noOneBehindTwo()
incrementCycle(), prefsUpdated[id] = false, H[id] = Hk(id), entropy = sum (r : robot) H[r]

query.comment:
How many cycles in total does robot 0 go through before consensus is reached.
Results: For 7 robots with random preferences in a fully connected graphs. [<=1000;5000] ≈ 2 (as expected)
Note: first 32.24 +- 6 with threshold 0.1 = 27.13 +- 4.08854
Note 2: Without empirical value (actually 0.1) (and network size 106): 29.51 +- 3.96507

plot.title: Probability Density Distribution
plot.comment: Parameters: α=0.05, ε=0.05, bucket width=1, bucket count=9 Runs: 100 in total, 100 (100%) displayed, 0 (0%) remaining Span of displayed sample: [2, 10] Mean estimate of displayed sample: 3.96 ± 0.2674 (95% CI)

query.comment: It would be nice to have the reverse query. Within this time, how much time does it take at most to reach this state? There should be a few edge cases where a robot takes one more cycle than the others. This is because of unknown interleavings that causes a single robot (seemingly a robot with only one neighbor) to not calculate their decision group size correctly at the first cycle where all robots agree.

query.comment: This shows a general tendency of decreasing entropy, so has clear effect
This one with threshold-value: value= 2 (network size 106) gives 25.84 +- 3.4, (so far lower than threshold 0.1, value, which was 29.51) There is an outlier, though
